<script>
    $(function() {
        let $mobile_header = $('.mobile-header');
        let $burger = $('.mobile-header .burger');
        let $menu_overlay = $('.mobile-header .menu-overlay');
        let $return = $('.mobile-header .return');

        let active = false;
        let level = 0;
        let $menu_root = $('.mobile-header .menu-root');

        let overlay_height = window.innerHeight - $('.mobile-header .top')[0].scrollHeight
            - $('.mobile-header .menu-bar')[0].scrollHeight;
        $('.mobile-header .menu-overlay').css({'height': overlay_height});

        $burger.on('click', function() {
            if (active) {
                active = false;
                $menu_overlay.fadeOut(200);
                $return.css({'opacity': 0});
                $mobile_header.css({'background-color': '#212E3B'});
                $burger.removeClass('active');
                $('body').css({'overflow': 'inherit'});
            } else {
                active = true;
                $menu_overlay.fadeIn(200);
                $return.css({'opacity': 1});
                $mobile_header.css({'background-color': '#121F29'});
                $burger.addClass('active');
                $('body').css({'overflow': 'hidden'});
            }
        });
        
        $return.on('click', function () {
            if (level < 1) return;

            $menu_root.find('> li > ul '.repeat(level)).removeClass('menu-active');
            level -= 1;
            $menu_root.css({'transform': 'translateX(' + (-level * 100) + 'vw)'});
            
            if (level === 0) {
                $return.css({'display': 'none'});
            }
        });
    
        $menu_root.on('click', function (event) {
            let $target = $(event.target);
            if ($target.hasClass('menu-button')) {
                level += 1;
                $menu_root.find('> li > ul '.repeat(level)).removeClass('menu-active');
                $target.children('ul').first().addClass('menu-active');
                $menu_root.css({'transform': 'translateX(' + (-level * 100) + 'vw)'});
                $return.css({'display': 'flex'});
            }
        });
        
        let last_scroll = window.scrollY, top = 0, max = $mobile_header.outerHeight();
        $(window).on('scroll', function() {
            top += last_scroll - window.scrollY;

            if (top < -max) top = -max;
            if (top > 0) top = 0;

            $mobile_header.css({'top': top + 'px'});
            last_scroll = window.scrollY;
        });
    });
</script>

<script>
    $(function() {
        let open = false;
        let active = null;
        let closeTimer = null;
        
        $('.desktop-header .menu-root .menu-button').on('mouseover', function() {
            let new_active = $(this).data('menu');
            
            if (active && active !== new_active) {
                $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + active).css({'display': 'none'});
                $('.desktop-header .menu-button').removeClass('active');
            }
            
            $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + new_active).css({'display': 'inherit'});
            $(this).addClass('active');
            active = new_active;
            
            let height = $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + active)[0].scrollHeight + 'px';
            $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'height': height});
            
            if (!open) {
                open = true;
                $('.desktop-header').addClass('active');
                $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'display': 'inherit'});
                
                if (height === '0px') {
                    height = $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + active)[0].scrollHeight + 'px';
                    $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'height': height});
                }
            }
        });
        
        $('.desktop-header').on('mouseover', function() {
           clearTimeout(closeTimer);
        });
        
        $('.desktop-header').on('mouseout', function() {
            if (open) {
                closeTimer = setTimeout(function() {
                    $('.desktop-header').removeClass('active');
                    $('.desktop-header .menu-button').removeClass('active');
                    
                    $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'height': '0'});

                    let _active = active;
                    setTimeout(function() {
                        $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + _active).css({'display': 'none'});
                    }, 250);
                    
                    active = null;
                    open = false;
                }, 400);
            }
        });
    });
</script>

							<figure class="content">
                                <div class="s-p-co-l">
								    <h2><img loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-13762" src="../../../../uploads/2017/05/pexels-photo-193349-e1495624985120.jpeg" alt="" width="746" height="388" /></h2>
<h2>Introduction</h2>
<p><strong>Emotet</strong> is a modular Trojan horse, which was firstly noticed in June 2014 by <a href="http://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/new-banking-malware-uses-network-sniffing-for-data-theft/">Trend Micro</a>. This malware is related to other types like Geodo, Bugat or Dridex, which are attributed by researches to the same family.</p>
<p>Emotet was discovered as an advanced banker &#8211; it&#8217;s first campaign targeted clients of German and Austrian banks. Victims&#8217; bank accounts were infiltrated by a web browser infection which intercept communication between webpage and bank servers. In such scenario, malware hooks specific routines to sniff network activity and steal information. This technique is typical for modern banking malware and is widely known as <strong>Man-in-the-Browser attack</strong>.</p>
<p>Next, modified release of Emotet banker (v2) has taken advantage of another technique &#8211; automation of stealing money from hijacked bank accounts using ATSs (Automated Transfer Systems, more informations on page 20 of <a href="../../../../uploads/2015/11/Report_CP_2013.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CERT Polska Report 2013</a>). This technology is also used in other bankers. Good examples are ISFB (Gozi) or Tinba.</p>
<p>At the beginning of April 2017, we observed <strong>wide malspam campaign in Poland</strong>, distributing fraudulent mails. E-mails were imitating delivery notifications from DHL logistics company and contained malicious link, which referred to brand-new, unknown variant of Emotet.</p>
<p><img class="size-full wp-image-13765 aligncenter" src="../../../../uploads/2017/05/mail.png" alt="" width="700" /></p>
<p>Malware distributed in this campaign differed from previously known versions. Behavior and communication methods were similar, but malware used <strong>different encryption</strong> and we noticed significant changes in its code. Thus we called this modification <strong>version 4</strong>.</p>
<p><span id="more-13778"></span></p>
<h2>Dropper</h2>
<p>Links from the phishing campaign pointed to a dropper, which downloaded and executed malware. Dropper was written in Javascript and wasn&#8217;t highly obfuscated. It was fairly easy to notice, that strings with distribution site URLs were just reversed.</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/psrok1/aba17d52a2a2e5b48a6404cd1b42b7c5.js"></script></p>
<p>Distribution sites found in dropper:</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text default" style="overflow:auto;white-space:nowrap;width:850px;"><div class="text codecolorer">hxxp://etherealmedia.co.uk/download6051/<br />
hxxp://intecsoftware.com/download1577/<br />
hxxp://danirvinphotography.com/download0303/<br />
hxxp://brandcastersmedia.com/download6493/<br />
hxxp://aktech.com.pl/download9674/</div></div>
<h2>Main module</h2>
<p>An interesting thing in Emotet is its modular structure. Main module dropped by script doesn&#8217;t contain anything harmful and is used only to download another modules from C&amp;C, which perform specific tasks. Sample dropped by script is protected using some generic packer to avoid recognition by AV software.</p>
<p>After unpacking, malware loads libraries and resolves WinAPI routines used in encryption and communication with C&amp;C. Names of specific functions are obfuscated and stored as array of hashes. Emotet uses simple <strong><a href="http://www.cse.yorku.ca/~oz/hash.html">sdbm</a></strong> hash function for this purpose. To make hashes more varied, values are additionally XORed with some constant specified in binary.</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/psrok1/5a67c3306080f62969e8d0e63a988b4e.js"></script></p>
<p>Strings that are distinctive for Emotet are also encoded using 4-byte XOR key, different for each string.</p>
<p>Main executable file contains also a list of IP addresses of C&amp;C servers. Similar to previous versions, sample communicates with Command&amp;Control using plain HTTP.</p>
<p><img loading="lazy" class="size-full wp-image-13747 aligncenter" src="../../../../uploads/2017/05/ips.png" alt="" width="666" height="240" /></p>
<h2>Encryption</h2>
<p>The most significant change in new version is usage of different encryption algorithm. In previous releases, communication was encrypted using RC4. In fourth version, Emotet switched to <strong>128-bit AES in CBC mode</strong>.</p>
<p>Intercepted request:</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text default" style="overflow:auto;white-space:nowrap;width:850px;"><div class="text codecolorer">GET / HTTP/1.1<br />
Cookie: <br />
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; SLCC1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322)<br />
Host: 206.214.220.79:8080<br />
Connection: Keep-Alive<br />
Cache-Control: no-cache</div></div>
<p>Request body is passed in Cookie header. Cookie&#8217;s key is random 16-bit hexadecimal number, with Base64-encoded binary blob as value.</p>
<p>After decoding, structure of request is described below:</p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><strong>Offset</strong></td>
<td><strong>Field name</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>0..95</td>
<td>asymmetrically encrypted 128-bit AES key used for request encryption</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>96..115</td>
<td>SHA1 hash of plaintext request body</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>116..x</td>
<td>Request body, AES-128-CBC encrypted</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Before sending, malware performs key generation. In the first stage, Emotet loads 768-bit RSA public key, stored in executable. Then, AES symmetric key is generated using cryptographically secure PRNG (CryptGenKey). Finally, generated key is encrypted using previously loaded public key and attached to the request using PKCS#1v2.0 (OAEP) padding.</p>
<p>Cryptography is based on Microsoft CryptoAPI mechanisms.</p>
<p><strong>Key generation and public key import</strong>:<br />
<script src="https://gist.github.com/psrok1/6386c5b9246c9673b24b39105571ff10.js"></script></p>
<p><strong>Request encryption</strong>:<br />
<script src="https://gist.github.com/psrok1/b2778a5929a7ee6ef6bf0eebd856b45e.js"></script></p>
<h2>Communication with C&amp;C</h2>
<p>Received response is presented below:<br />
<img loading="lazy" class="wp-image-13742 aligncenter" src="../../../../uploads/2017/05/emotetreq.png" alt="" width="590" height="248" /></p>
<p>Communication protocol is based on <a href="https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers">Google Protocol Buffers</a>. Protocol Buffers is a mechanism, which allows developers to simply build own protocols using set of message structure declarations, written in a specific protobuf language. Protocol Buffers generates parsing and serializing modules, which can be directly used in developed solution. Protobuf supports wide set of languages, including Python, Java, PHP or C++. Using this kind of mechanisms isn&#8217;t something new in malware, protobuf-based protocols can be found for example in <a href="https://securelist.com/blog/research/76433/inside-the-gootkit-cc-server/">Gootkit</a> malware.</p>
<p>Unfortunately, Emotet&#8217;s case is a bit different. Protobuf code inside malware is <strong>slightly modified</strong> and provides additional type of encoding, which is not specified in the original Protocol Buffers documentation. Because of this small difference, response can&#8217;t be properly decoded using generic protobuf parsers e.g. <em>protoc</em> with <em>&#8211;decode_raw</em> argument fails.</p>
<p>Anyway, original protocol definitions were successfully reversed:<br />
<script src="https://gist.github.com/psrok1/5e5ee4890c549a673d561c62ff1ebafb.js"></script></p>
<p>Registration request contains command id (16) and some information about host operating system. Each field of <strong>RegistrationRequestBody</strong> structure has been described below:</p>
<p><strong>botId field</strong></p>
<p>This field provides information about values specific to victim&#8217;s machine and probably is meant to be unique between bot instances.</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text default" style="overflow:auto;white-space:nowrap;width:850px;"><div class="text codecolorer">[host_name]_[locale]_[host_id]<br />
e.g. CERTCERT_PL_32122958</div></div>
<ul class="cert_li_before"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>host_name</strong> &#8211; contains only chars from 0..9a..zA..Z- charset, another chars are replaced by &#8216;?&#8217;</li>
<li><strong>locale</strong> &#8211; contains information about locale settings. In this case, dash &#8216;-&#8216; is also forbidden</li>
<li><strong>host_id</strong> &#8211; 32-bit hexadecimal value of sdbm hash (used also by API resolver) from current user login xored by Windows drive serial number.</li>
</ul>
<p></ul>
<p><strong>osVersion field</strong></p>
<p>32-bit field, which describes version of Windows running on infected host. It&#8217;s a bit field, where each groups of bits contains specific value of <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms724833.aspx">OSVERSIONINFOEX</a> structure.</p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><strong>Bits</strong></td>
<td><strong>Description</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>0..3</td>
<td>dwMajorVersion</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>4..7</td>
<td>dwMinorVersion</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>8..11</td>
<td>wServicePackMajor</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>12..15</td>
<td>wServicePackMinor</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>16..19</td>
<td>wProductType</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>20..23</td>
<td>SYSTEM_INFO.wProcessorArchitecture</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><strong>procList field</strong></p>
<p>Contains comma-separated list of currently running process names.</p>
<p><strong>mailClient field</strong></p>
<p>Provides information about used mail client (read from &#8220;HKLM\Software\Clients\Mail&#8221; registry key value). If it&#8217;s Microsoft Outlook and it&#8217;s MAPI DLL is 64-bit, name is followed by &#8221; x64&#8243; suffix.</p>
<h2>Response</h2>
<p>If a registration request was received, C&amp;C server returns a list of Emotet modules. HTTP status response is always <strong>404 Not Found</strong>, regardless of the fact whether request was built properly or not. In this case, response body contains encrypted response.</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text default" style="overflow:auto;white-space:nowrap;width:850px;"><div class="text codecolorer">HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found<br />
Server: nginx<br />
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8<br />
Content-Length: 728740<br />
Connection: keep-alive<br />
<br />
alc:*qLud&amp;lt;d^GÌ¾&amp;gt;...</div></div>
<p>Structure of encrypted response is quite similar to the request structure. Encrypted payload starts at 116-byte of received message. Response is encrypted using the same AES key, which was passed in request. After successful decryption, we obtain protobuf-like message with list of MZ binaries or URLs.</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/psrok1/ebbb7ccd0ac873053cfc4473c8f8c009.js"></script></p>
<p>In this case, malware uses non-standard encoding. Field <em>repeated Module modules = 1 [packed=true];</em> is illegal in protobuf language, because <em>packed</em> attribute can be used only for primitive numeric type of repeated fields. Surprisingly, list of modules is encoded like packed list of <em>Message</em> objects.</p>
<p>Here is a low-level C&amp;C response description, using <a href="https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/encoding">Protocol Buffers encoding</a> primitives:</p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><strong>Type</strong></td>
<td><strong>Name</strong></td>
<td><strong>Comment</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="3"><center><strong>ModuleResponse</strong></center></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>TAG</td>
<td>tag</td>
<td>0x0a</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>VARINT</td>
<td>length of &#8216;modules&#8217; list</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="3"><center><strong>Module</strong> (repeated)</center></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>VARINT</td>
<td colspan="2">length of Module element</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>TAG</td>
<td>&#8216;type&#8217; field tag</td>
<td>0x08</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>VARINT</td>
<td colspan="2">type</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>TAG</td>
<td>&#8216;blob&#8217; field type</td>
<td>0x12</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>VARINT</td>
<td colspan="2">length of &#8216;blob&#8217;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>RAW</td>
<td colspan="2">&#8216;blob&#8217; content</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="3"><center>&#8230;</center></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>It should be noted that elements of Modules are repeated <strong>without Module message tag</strong>, which is specific to <em>packed</em> encoding,</p>
<p><strong>type field</strong></p>
<p>This field defines type of blob content and specifies method of module execution. Type field can be one of the following values:</p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><strong>Value</strong></td>
<td><strong>Description</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1</td>
<td>Store in %TEMP% and execute with -U argument</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2</td>
<td>Like &#8216;1&#8217;, but without arguments</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>3</td>
<td>Download and execute file from URL specified &#8216;blob&#8217;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>4</td>
<td>Use own internal loader &#8211; load and execute PE file from &#8216;blob&#8217;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>5</td>
<td>Uninstall &#8211; delete related &#8216;.lnk&#8217; from Startup folder</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>default</td>
<td>Do nothing</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2>Modules</h2>
<p>In previous versions, Emotet modules were providing the following set of functionalities:<br />
<ul class="cert_li_before"></p>
<ul>
<li>Stealing money from bank accounts (Man-in-the-Browser attack)</li>
<li>Spreading by sending spam e-mails</li>
<li>Stealing mails and credentials to mail accounts</li>
<li>DDoS module</li>
<li>Stealing browsing history and passwords from web browser</li>
</ul>
<p></ul></p>
<p>In version 4 distributed in the last campaign, we didn&#8217;t observe banking module, which is somewhat unusual for this type of malware. Behavior of other modules was quite similar to previous versions. During analysis, we successfully dropped two types of modules, described below:</p>
<p><strong>Credentials stealer</strong></p>
<p>In server response, we found two similar modules, which purpose was to <strong>steal credentials from web browser and mail client</strong>. Both modules have embedded NirSoft password recovery software inside:<br />
<ul class="cert_li_before"></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.nirsoft.net/utils/mailpv.html">Mail PassView (Email Password-Recovery)</a> v1.86</li>
<li><a href="http://www.nirsoft.net/utils/web_browser_password.html">WebBrowserPassView</a> v1.80</li>
</ul>
<p></ul></p>
<p>Recovery software was embedded as XOR-encoded static blob, using 32-bit key (similar to strings). On module startup, software was decoded and stored in <em>%TEMP%</em>, and then executed with <em>/scomma [temp file name]</em> parameter, which leads to dump all passwords into file contained in <em>%TEMP%</em> folder (name generated using <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa364991.aspx">GetTempFileNameW</a>). Stealed data were sent to C&amp;C server for malware spreading purpose.</p>
<p><strong>Spam module</strong></p>
<p>Second type of module was spam module, used for malware spreading. Firstly, module asks C&amp;C for message template, list of recipients and list of hijacked accounts, which will be used to spam distribution.</p>
<p>Request structure presents as below:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/psrok1/2aeeb3aa9b1c89f79d9014f2db2bb62d.js"></script></p>
<p>Fields <em>flags</em> and <em>additionalData</em> specify, which data has been received from server and which we&#8217;re expecting in C&amp;C answer.</p>
<p>Server response looks like below:<br />
<script src="https://gist.github.com/psrok1/ec163f03a0dbf0c62bf69dba506eb53d.js"></script></p>
<p>E-mails are not sent using local account. Distribution is performed using <strong>previously scrapped mail accounts</strong>, which are sent to each spambot.</p>
<p>Message template example:</p>
<div class="codecolorer-container text default" style="overflow:auto;white-space:nowrap;width:850px;"><div class="text codecolorer">Hello &lt;span style=&quot;text-transform: uppercase;&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;<br />
<br />
Thank you for your order. The details can be found below.<br />
<br />
Invoice attached: &lt;a href=&quot;http://aceeight.com/Cust-000564-17424/&quot;&gt;http://aceeight.com/Cust-000564-17424/&amp;lt;&amp;gt;&lt;/a&gt;<br />
<br />
This e-mail was sent by &lt;span style=&quot;text-transform: uppercase;&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;&amp;gt;<br />
&amp;lt;&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;</div></div>
<h2>Summary</h2>
<p>Basic functionality of Emotet in last campaign was just stealing credentials and spreading. Even though, malware is still active and also actively developed. Because of lack of few important modules, Emotet will be probably extended in future. In case of infection, we recommend <strong>changing passwords</strong> to all accounts, which credentials were stored in mail client or web browser.</p>
<h2>Additional informations</h2>
<ul class="cert_li_before"></p>
<ul>
<li>Detailed <a href="https://securelist.com/analysis/publications/69560/the-banking-trojan-emotet-detailed-analysis/">Kaspersky analysis from 2015</a> (Emotet v2 and v3)</li>
</ul>
<p></ul>
